subject: Re: Unicode proposal, yet again.

messageBody:
That is excellent news and this maybe beside the point but I did
just want to point out that there are more variations to characters
than those listed in the proposal and that some characters have more
than one variation. Thus it seems that the variants listed are
incomplete and the selector to toggle between the standard and one
_single_ variant is not enough to work with Senior. As it stands the
proposal is much needed and wonderfully complete for Junior QS it's
just that it would have to be expanded for Senior.
I absolutely revel in the idea of having our own Unicode range as
soon as possible. I just want to make sure we are able to get enough
slots for Senior. But I certainly don't have any expertise in writing
Unicode proposals and for all I know changing the proposal for Senior
latter is perfectly simple.

If interested, here are a few rather dull observations to support my
claim:

As we know, it turns out that in Senior QS, there are far more
variations to letters implied in Read's Quickscript Manual (QM) than
are explicitly mentioned in that book. For example:
- For each half letter glyph, there must be a step variation as well
as a non-step variation. This already implies a normal form plus 2
variations for at least 4 letters.
- The glyph See that joins a following glyph Tea can not be the same
as a glyph See that joins a following Pea. (One sees both the ST and
SP joins in the manual but explicit mention of the variation is not
made.) Quite simply there would be no way to write both "stop" and
"spot" correctly without addition variations no mater what rendering
engine is used.
- The Roe + Ice (eg "pry") must involve different glyphs than Ice +
Roe (eg "mire")
- The At + May in "am" vs the May + Ice in "my"
- The See and Utter glyphs in "some" vs the See and Utter used in
other words.
- The possible permutations of these variations
- There are more but I won't bore you. It would be nice to make a
comprehensive list and I will be very happy to contribute. A reference
implementation of a Senior editing tool would help which,
coincidentally, is what I'm building ;->

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, amd64_hacker <amd64_hacker@...>
wrote:
>
> Don't worry it isn't a concern.
> Unicode is only concerned with the logical storage/processing of
characters.
> Presentation, which is what the differences in junior/senior QS really
> boil down to, is handled by the rendering layer.
>
> I'm reasonably certain that truetype is sufficient for senior QS.
> Arabic fonts, for example, are much more complicated and they seem to be
> quite possible.
> I must admit I'm not very clear on how contextual substitution works in
> truetype.
> The official TTF documentation has been moved to the Microsoft site and
> I get the feeling that they'd much rather you bought the book.
> The pages are laid out in a way which I find makes gathering any
> information from them rather difficult, although that might just be my
> lack of experience with fonts in general.
>
> othermale wrote:
> >
> > If I may weigh in, I know its rather a large thing to bring up but my
> > only concern is that we may want rethink our coverage of Senior
> > QuickScript in the Unicode proposal. I say this with immense
> > reluctance since Senior is my particular joy but I have several
> > reasons never the less:
> >
> > 1. The set of glyphs included in the current Unicode proposal omits a
> > large number critical variations necessary for Senior QS (one example:
> > the way "Roe" attaches to following "Ice". Another example: the "Roe"
> > + "Zoo" which is found in rendering Mrs. ). Being limited to this
> > reduced Senior QS set results in writing that is neither Senior nor
> > Junior but an undocumented and inconsistent hybrid which I suggest we
> > do not wish to permanently embed in the Unicode standard.
> >
> > 2. From what I have read, Junior was intended to be used for
> > typographic purposes and Senior was not. Although this decision was no
> > doubt made in an era of typewriters and manual typesetting, even now
> > the TrueType font rendering specification (anchors and scripts et al),
> > are inadequate to properly render Senior.
> >
> > In my humble opinion, I suggest removing those glyphs which try to
> > support Senior QS and proceed with a purely Junior QS set of glyphs
> > until the considerable Senior QS requirements are full described.
> > Personally I would desperately like to see Senior QS in the Unicode
> > standard and would love to contribute as much as I can to such a
> > proposal if you think it appropriate. Indeed, I have made fair headway
> > in locating the needs for Senior QS and I would enthusiastically post
> > what I have found if you believe it will be of use but I can not claim
> > it is complete yet.
> >
> >
>
